I thought any force applied to the center of mass would result in no torque since it would be F*0m. Since the ladder is in equilibrium, the direction of the total force from the floor is not and cannot be exactly on the line of the ladder. To be more precise the line of the force from the floor has to pass through the point the line of the weight and the line of the force from the wall intersect.  If anyone wants any further explanation just ask.

First, the shear modulus is represented by G. This modulus is also sometimes referred to as the modulus of rigidity. Shear stress is represented by tau I believe. Next, in most civil engineering settings there's not really a risk of confusion since the W=mg is sufficient, no need to bust out the equation using the gravitational constant. At least it was in my statics course. However, my experience with things like this is that you quickly learn that a single letter could represent any number of quantities. My physics professor would usually say something like "mu only represents..." and would begin listing off things that it is used for.﻿ ﻿

If you use S then how do you avoid confusion with the action S!?  Ofcourse in physics you just use whatever letter is convenient at the time, there is no possible way to give every single concept in physics its own unique letter.
s is used for bolt spacing, which is either dependent on the shear force or the tensile force applied to what the bolt is holding together. So your solution to the conundrum would only add confusion.
Ok, then use upside down capital pi to represent shear stress or {{S}}.

namename8888888888 But if you use an upside down capital pi to represent shear stress how do you avoid confusion with the coproduct, or if you use {{S}} how do you avoid confusion with the set of the set of S!?

Rich animations and Game of Thrones references are fun, but they are disservice for the material being teached.

I'm a medical student and we mentioned Young's module when learning bone diseases (such as osteoporosis and osteogenesis imperfecta) but I can't currently remember how it changes in those conditions...
+Nightraven26   Time to review your notes.  You did take notes?  You did attend the lecture?

Mark Holm yup, but I also learned 500 pages of systemic pathology in the meantime with the lovely eponyms such as Marie-Strümpell-Bechterew disease, Legg-Calve-Perthes syndrome, Binswanger disease, Libman-Sacks endocarditis, Charcot-Marie-Tooth and Dejerine Sottas, etc. etc. And since I want to be a surgeon, I don't really think that the level of bendiness of bones will be necessary to know in my everyday clinical practice.

+Nightraven26   It strikes me that what happens to bone, at least the basics, during degenerative bone diseases is the sort of basic knowledge all physicians and surgeons ought to  carry in their heads.  I have a couple of friends who are physicians, one a med school professor.  They pride themselves on a wide knowledge of medicine, even that outside their specialties.  The med school professor is also an active nephrologist.  A common observation from him is making diagnoses outside his specialty that other physicians have missed in his patients

+Nightraven26   Also, writing here as a physical scientist (chemist) and a consumer of health care services, I don't think I would want to be seen, certainly not operated on, by a surgeon who is not bright enough, and who does not have a decent enough basic science background, to figure out what happens to the modulus of bone as a result of a demineralizing condition.  You can not memorize everything in medicine, or any other branch of science.  You have to learn how things work.  Hmmm, I seem to remember Captain Kirk saying something like that.
